comment._content: Interesting  -  Looks like west Galway or South west  Mayo, probably Connemara. Could the poser be an American and the N is missing or erased?

comment.author: 77199267@N03
comment._content: If it is Mayo, I would also put it in south west Mayo with those stone walls and the mountains. It looks like it's a view facing south or south west with the Connemara hills in the distance.

comment.author: 77199267@N03
comment._content: This is as close as I can get to a streetview I think the photographer may have been standing on the site of the quarry to the right - it may have been more elevated at the time...or perhaps where the big gorse bush is now.

comment.author: 77199267@N03
comment._content: The name is really curious. The only reference to it that I can find online is on the NLI catalogue and the OS Map. Makes me think that someone was taking the proverbial out of the OS men when they were naming places. "What's the name of this place?" "Ah, sure this is America (ya amadán)"

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/77199267@N03] On the Dail Record as the American Junction


Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Special Grants for Galway Roads.

Thursday, 15 December 1955
Mr. Bartley:   asked the Minister for Local Government whether special grants for tourist roads will be allocated in the next financial year for the improvement of all or any of the roads from (a) Cashel Cross to Toombeola, (b) Moycullen through Callownamuck to Oldchapel, (c) Streamstown Bridge to Cleggan, (d) Tully Cross to Salruck, (e) Cornamona to Cloughbrack, (f) Cloughbrack Cross (American Junction) to Drishagaun, (g) Cornamona to Dooras, (h) Dooghty West to Crimlin, and (i) Cleggan to Moyard Bridge, County Galway.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: Another oddity: America is clearly in Galway, not Mayo, and always was.

comment.author: 66340104@N05
comment._content: Must remember to avoid prairie potatoes if I ever see them on a menu ;-)

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content: Looking for the details of a gravestone for Sergeant James N MONSON who died 21 June 1890 at America Hut, RIC, Clonbur aged 39. He died of Typhus and thus his body could not be returned to his native area of Coolnagrashny, Boyle and he was buried in the churchyard at Clonbur. He left a wife and young children and hopefully the gravestone may have those details or, those of his parents.

comment.author: 66151649@N02
comment._content: I googled America, Co. Galway, and you get this: www.fantompowa.net/Flame/che_guevara_irish_roots.htm Che Guevara was Irish?! That could be Che's relative with the cart...

comment.author: 91549360@N03
comment._content: Re; the Constabulary Hut...Or the America Hut as it's called on the 1911 enumerators return. This is listed as a stone building with slate roof. The front wall still stands. www.google.com/maps?ll=53.557314,-9.453778&spn=0.0062...

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: The America, Co. Mayo limerick There once was a woman called Erica Who wanted to go to America. She paid a huge fare But ended up here, Cursing all men who, er, trick her.

comment.author: 83105385@N04
comment._content: Yup theres a Baile Mheiricea in Cloughbrack at a junction just beyond the quarry. Has anyone more old photos of the area? My grandad was the school master of the school in Cloughbrack, Master Burke, and my grandads (Mairtin Coyne) house was in the film, The Railway Children, although Im not too sure where this house is now, if anyone knows anything else about the area that would be great, Aoife McDermott here contactable on effamcd@yahoo.co.uk

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/83105385@N04] Hi Aoife! You could try searching in our photo collections for places near Cloughbrack (intrigued to see there's a Cloughbrack Near and a Cloughbrack Far) as we've over 1,000 digitised photos of Mayo. If you have place names, you can considerably narrow down that figure...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 46272871@N04
comment._content: Here is a photo of part of the intersection at which the plaque Baile Mheiricea is placed in the stone wall. The road in the old picture above is likely the one would take westward as indicated in the sign at the intersection (direction Gleanntreig - Glen of Desolation) www.flickr.com/photos/rjcon/10784305986/ This road, I believe, leads to Cloughbrack Upper where my cousin Pat lives in a home just over the rise seen in the photo. On the right and out of the photo ought to be a portion of Lough Mask. Here is a closer view of the plaque. www.flickr.com/photos/rjcon/10784399744/in/photostream/

comment.author: 46272871@N04
comment._content: There was a border shift between Mayo and Galway in 1898 which may account for the confusion in the notation on the photo. freepages.genealogy.rootsweb.ancestry.com/~mcging/border....
